sentences.sentence: By Becket AdamsWashington Examiner(https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/ )For the millionth time, journalists: Stop taking your cues from social media!It is lazy.

It can also lead to painfully embarrassing moments, including the one where MSNBC's Brian Williams and New York Times editorial board member Mara Gay asserted that $500 million could be divvied up to provide 327 million individuals with exactly $1 million apiece.It is painful to have to say this, but $500 million dollars, divided up, would provide $1 million to no more than 500 people.
This leaves 326,999,500 people who get nothing if it is indeed divided into millions.The moment came Thursday evening as Williams and May highlighted a tweet by Twitter user "Mekita Rivas.
"The tweet, which I am fairly certain is a joke, reads, "Bloomberg spent $500 million on ads.
The U.S. population is 327 million.
He could have given each American $1 million and still have money left over.
I feel like a $1 million check would be life-changing for most people.
Yet he wasted it on ads and STILL LOST.

"https://t.co/kiJ7cqhQri(https://t.co/kiJ7cqhQri)-Bad Econ Takes (@BadEconTakes) March 05, 2020(http://twitter.com/#!/BadEconTakes/status/1235660604179746816)Five hundred million dollars split evenly among 327 million people means everyone would get roughly $1.50.
The Bloomberg campaign could have bought everyone in America a small cup of coffee.

Yet, despite the fact that Rivas's tweet is a steaming load of nonsense, it managed somehow to make it all the way to MSNBC's 11th Hour, where host Brian Williams and guest Mara Gay marveled, furrow-browed, at the supposedly disturbing implications of the Twitter user's hilariously, obviously faulty assertion.
"When I read it tonight on social media," said Williams, "it kind of all became clear....
It's an incredible way of putting it.
"Gay, who once blamed the federal government for broken water pipes in East Harlem, New York, added, "It's an incredible way of putting it.
It's true.
It's disturbing.
"By the way, it is most certainly not true.
"It does suggest, you know, what we are talking about here, which is: There is too much money in politics," she added.There it is!
That is why Rivas's tweet was highlighted by a major MSNBC news program despite its laughable error.
The tweet confirmed the prejudices of host and guest alike, that there was "too much money in politics."

Williams and Gay were primed already to trust Rivas's conclusion, so they gave little thought to the bad arithmetic that got her there.Even worse, Williams and Gay were not the only ones who saw the tweet prior to its broadcast and fell for it.
For the tweet to appear on-air, it first had to go through an entire production team, including producers and assistants.
Think about it: At least five or six people read Rivas's tweet before it aired, and not one of them noticed what amounts to a basic, grade school-level arithmetic error.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
